
An intern reused primes for two RSA keys, but both are blum integers. The intercepted message: 52870914144528547709964903681111855790164693079339309933830752511285255627497431069921362184548984208083207801632936823177937850398414508436435095019532. Can you decrypt it and expose their mistake?


The flag format is flag{...}
n=6102200748344094695695356836983144120988523051152838643612104190491545980123417055388829624789693222209848124448565266361777610419689627321971549841853641, e=3232589792448302072763034900176184086699412633219404919241267375169256708423555264364564599101219028359046828555479580026243999744491801935937784611184939
The lower 104 bits of p are: 10703254805945273238521024270612382687

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{ela9yc8y}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 52870914144528547709964903681111855790164693079339309933830752511285255627497431069921362184548984208083207801632936823177937850398414508436435095019532
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6102200748344094695695356836983144120988523051152838643612104190491545980123417055388829624789693222209848124448565266361777610419689627321971549841853641, e=3232589792448302072763034900176184086699412633219404919241267375169256708423555264364564599101219028359046828555479580026243999744491801935937784611184939
